Class GrammarSolver

  • java.lang.Object
    • GrammarSolver

  • public class GrammarSolver
extends java.lang.Object
    This object is utilized by GrammarMain.java and accepts an immutable list of grammar rules, seperated by "::=" and "|" then parses it and returns randomly generated sentences from it when calling generate().
    Since:
    1.0

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      GrammarSolver(java.util.List<java.lang.String> rules)
      Constructor, takes an unmodifiable list of grammar lines and creates a rule map out of it, initializes GrammarSolver's random object.

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      boolean contains(java.lang.String symbol)
      Checks to see if the entered symbol exists in the rule map, returns true if so.
      java.lang.String generate(java.lang.String symbol)
      Generates a phrase of words from the given symbol using the rule map.
      java.util.Set<java.lang.String> getSymbols()
      Returns a sorted set of Non-Terminals available in the rule map.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Constructor Detail

      • GrammarSolver

        public GrammarSolver(java.util.List<java.lang.String> rules)
        Constructor, takes an unmodifiable list of grammar lines and creates a rule map out of it, initializes GrammarSolver's random object.
        Parameters:
        rules - The list of grammar lines used to populate the ruleMap
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if list is null or list length < 1
        Precondition:
        List elements must be seperate lines of grammar rules, starting with the non-terminal follow by ::= and its terminals, each AND terminal must be seperated by whitespace and each OR terminal seperated by pipes (|). If non-terminal references itself as a terminal, must include a way to end the loop eventually, such as giving another terminal option with a pipe (|)., List must not be empty, List must not be null
        Postcondition:
        Instantiates a GrammarSolver object with initialized rule map

    • Method Detail

      • contains

        public boolean contains(java.lang.String symbol)
        Checks to see if the entered symbol exists in the rule map, returns true if so.
        Parameters:
        symbol - The non-terminal string entered by the user
        Returns:
        True if symbol is a Non-Terminal, false otherwise
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if symbol is null or list length < 1
        Precondition:
        String must not be empty, String must not be null

      • getSymbols

        public java.util.Set<java.lang.String> getSymbols()
        Returns a sorted set of Non-Terminals available in the rule map.
        Returns:
        A set of non-terminal keys to generate phrases from

      • generate

        public java.lang.String generate(java.lang.String symbol)
        Generates a phrase of words from the given symbol using the rule map.
        Parameters:
        symbol - The non-terminal string entered by the user
        Returns:
        The symbol given if it is not a non-terminal, otherwise a string of words randomly picked from the terminals of the symbol given.
        Throws:
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - if symbol is null or list length < 1
        Precondition:
        Symbol given must exist as a non-terminal., String must not be empty., String must not be null.
        Postcondition:
        Will return a string of random terminals from the given non-terminal, assuming the symbol exists as a non-terminal, it contains terminal values to pick from, the syntax rules were followed, and a non-terminal referencing itself does not create an infinite loop.
